text: A country lane c. 1960 with MISS SHEPHERD at the wheel of van barrelling along, her face set and anxious. Distantly hear the sound of a police siren (or bell it would be in 1960). She pulls the van into a side road or clearing and waits, ducking behind the seat as she sees the police car pass the end of the road. MISS SHEPHERD rights herself, checks the side of the van. Wipes her hand on it. Blood. crosses herself. Then starts up the van and drives off th way she has come. As she turns the corner, we see that the police car has stopped at the end of the road. A solitary policeman, UNDERWOOD, gets out of the car and watches the van disapp ROLL TITLES over —

A glamorous pianist in a décolleté evening gown (along th lines of Anne Todd in 'The Seventh Veil' c. 1947) playing some bravura piano concerto. As the titles end, so does the concerto, and we hear ALAN BENNETT in voice over and cut to -
ALAN BENNETT at his desk, writing.

The smell is sweet, with urine only a minor component, the prevalent odour suggesting the inside of someone's ear. Dank clothes are there too, wet wool and onions, which she eats raw, plus what for me has always been the essence of poverty, damp newspaper. The sound of the lavatory flushing. ALAN BENNETT looks towards the toilet door.  4/6 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 2.

Miss Shepherd's multi-flavoured aroma is masked by a liberal application of various talcum powders, with Yardley's Lavender always a favourite, and currently it is this genteel fragrance that dominates, the second subject, as it were, in her odoriferous concerto. MISS SHEPHERD comes out of the lavatory, pulls down her skirt, and leaves through the front door. We see somethin the inside of the house and its contents, still at this d c. 1976, fairly uncluttered.

But as she goes the original theme returns, her own primary odour now triumphantly restated and left hanging in the house long after she has departed. Out of the window we see Miss Shepherd's van parked in th drive and MISS SHEPHERD herself rearranges some plastic b beneath the van. She is tall and though her changes of costume will not be described in detail, she is generally dressed in an assortment of coats and headscarves but wit variety of other hats superimposed on the headscarves. Ol raincoats figure, as do carpet slippers and skirts which often been lengthened by the simple process of sewing on additional strips of material. She is about sixty-five.
(at the desk, speaks) Tell her. As he watches through the window, A.B. - his other self - comes out of the house.
A.B. approaches the van. A.B. (at the van) Miss Shepherd. In future I would prefer it if you didn't use my lavatory. There are lavatories at the bottom of the High Street. Use those.
They smell. I’m by nature a very clean person. (MORE )

I have a testimonial for a Clean Room, awarded me some years ago, and do you know my aunt, herself spotless said I was the cleanest of my mother’s children, (A.B. gives up, and goes) particularly in the unseen places.
A.B. catches ALAN BENNETT'S eye as he passes the study do

The writer is double. There is the self who does the writing and there is the self who does the living. And they talk. They argue. Writing is talking to one’s self, and I've been doing it all my life, and long before I first saw this house five years ago.

Five years earlier, possibly with a subtitle, though the unkempt nature of the house and a ‘For Sale’ sign indicat that this is earlier. House empty. No van. A.B. comes round the corner of Inverness Street into Gloucester Crescent, and then into the garden with an EST
Fifteen?

Number 10 fetched seventeen. A.B. looks discouraged. ESTATE AGENT (CONT’D) Come on. I thought you had a play on in the West End. These houses have got so much potential. Once you get rid of the junk. Well there you have it: Gloucester Crescent. Good street. On the up and up. A.B. and the ESTATE AGENT walk up Gloucester Crescent. Th street is alive with refurbishing activity. As he speaks workmen bring out a nice marble fireplace out of No. 63 a shove it in the skip, breaking it in the process. More workmen carry materials into another house.  10 11 12 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 4. ESTATE AGENT (CONT’D) Big motor, have you? Loads of room.
A.B. carries boxes of books into the empty study. Through window we see two men unloading a table or desk from a removal van. The sign now says 'Sold'.
A.B. leaves the house A.B.

The van stalled nearby, opposite a Convent. From MISS SHEPHERD'S POV we see A.B., with a WHSmith bag, through t van windscreen which is grimy, with the dashboard hosting variety of objects like a half-eaten tin of baked beans, packet of biscuit also half-eaten, various tissues, packe of soap flakes etc. A.B. stops to look at a cross (with a painted crucified Christ). MISS SHEPHERD appears at his shoulder.
You're not St John, are you? A.B. St John who?
St John. The disciple whom Jesus loved. A.B. No. My name's Bennett.
Well, if you're not St John I need a push for the van. It's conked out, the battery possibly. I put some water in only it hasn't done the trick. A.B. Was it distilled water?
It was holy water so it doesn't matter if it was distilled or not. The oil is another possibility.  12b 13 14 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 5. A.B. That's not holy too?

Holy oil in a van? It would be far too expensive. I want pushing round the corner. EXT. CONVENT. DAY 12b A.B. starts to push. MISS SHEPHERD goes though her repert of hand signals: 'I am moving off .. I am turning left' . movements done with boneless grace and in textbook Highwa Code fashion. A.B. Are you wanting to go far?
Possibly. I'm in two minds.
A police car passes. MISS SHEPHERD stops the van and crou down. MISS SHEPHERD emerges cautiously. A.B. Is that it?
I need the other end. A.B. That's half a mile away.
I'm in dire need of assistance. I'm a sick woman, dying possibly, just looking for a last resting place, somewhere to lay my head. Do you know of anywhere? A.B. goes
Bye bye madam. Mind how you go.
A.B. is back in the study, empty except for the desk and boxes of books piled high, which he has started to unpack  15 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 6.
A proper writer might welcome such an encounter as constituting experience. Me, I have to wait and mull it over.
She saw you coming. A.B. She's old.
You wouldn't get Harold Pinter pushing a van down the street. A.B. No. Unlike me. But then, I’m too busy not writing plays, and leading my mad, vigorous creative life.
Yeah. You live it. I write it.
MISS SHEPHERD'S POV inside the van driving slowly round t street, sussing it out. As she passes no. 23 her POV: A.B. outside with his bike, with RUFUS and PAULINE, neighbours living opposite.
Pretty house, not as big as ours, of course; but you're unattached. A.B. No. It's attached to the house behind.

No, you. You're...single. Sickert once lived in the street, apparently; Dickens’ abandoned wife. Now it's the usual north London medley: advertising, journalism, TV, people like you - writers, 'artists'. Anything in the pipeline? A.B. Well, I've got a play on in the West End.
Of course you have. Dare one ask?  16 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 7. A.B. Thirteen five.
Oh my God! A.B. I know.
And we're twice as big, so what does that make ours worth?
Mind you, our new neighbour won't help the prices. Shot of the van now parked at the top of the street. A.B. Yes, we’ve met.
Last year it was Gloucester Avenue. Now it's our turn.
She seems to have settled at 66. A.B. Will they mind?
I hope not. We like to think we’re a community. A.B. rides off on his bike.
What play has he got on?
We saw it. That domestic thing.
(thinks, then shakes her head) Gone.

Later. Plastic bags being hurled under the van by MISS SHEPHERD. Through the open window of No.42 we hear the so of children playing London's Burning on their recorders, this scene goes on, another small child arrives, lugging cello home. FIONA PERRY comes out of the house.  17 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 8.
(to Miss Shepherd) We thought you might like some pears. They’re from our garden in Suffolk.
Pears repeat on me. She goes on hurling bags.
Were you planning on staying long?
Not with that din going on. MISS SHEPHERD gets in the van, and closes the door. FIONA goes back into her garden where her husband is waiting.
I know what you’re thinking. Still, it’s nice to feel we're doing our bit for the homeless. GILES PERRY, her husband, says nothing.

location: 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. STAIRS AND BEDROOM. DAY 17

text: A.B. showing a young ACTOR round. The house is nearly emp A.B. I'd like to keep it like this. Simple.
Monastic. A.B. Quite. (moving into the bedroom) This is my bedroom.
Nice. A.B. So do you like being in the play?
Love it. Love it. So English. Just what people want. Bed looks comfortable.. A.B. Well maybe you could come round and give me a hand with the decorating.  18 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 9.

Sure. My girlfriend’s a dab hand at the painting. The ACTOR looks out of the window and sees MISS SHEPHERD pushing her wheelie past. ACTOR (CONT’D) On hello darling. You look a character. A.B. Well yes this is Camden Town. During the course of the film the house should gradually up with stuff so that at the finish there's as much clutt (of a superior kind) as the van.

A.B. gives sixpence to MISS SHEPHERD, who is sitting on t pavement which is covered with messages she has chalked u like 'St. Francis hurled money from him' and 'Say No to t Common Market'. There is also a pile of pamphlets, one of which A.B. take She is just chalking in some rudimentary birds.

Yes I’m here most days, I teach... and the pavement is my blackboard. I also sell pencils. A gentlemen came by the other day and said that the pencil he had bought from me was the best pencil on the market at the present time. A.B. (reading leaflet) You're against the Common Market, I see.
Me? Who said it was me? A.B. You’re not the writer?

Not necessarily. I'll go so far as to say this. They are anonymous. And they are a shilling. You’ve only given me sixpence.  20 21 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 10. A.B. (pointing to the pavement) It says there St Francis hurled money from him.
Yes, only he was a saint. He could afford to.
(coming out of the bank and tripping over her) Sodding beggars.
I am not a beggar. I am self- employed. And this gentleman is my neighbour.
MISS SHEPHERD is putting her bags back in the van.
Oh. On the move again? You didn’t stay long.
No. Because it was non-stop music.
Lucy is doing her O levels.
It’s the noise levels I’m worried about. She prepares to move off.
RUFUS and PAULINE in evening dress, with a picnic hamper blankets, about to get into a cab. They wave to A.B.
Sorry about all this. Glyndebourne.

‘Cosi'. A.B. Lucky you. Have fun. As the cab goes up the street we see MISS SHEPHERD in her van, doing her elaborate hand signals and slowly moving d the Crescent.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 11.
Oh, look out. Madam’s on the move.
So whose turn will it be now? (To the cab driver.) Slow down.
(looking at his watch) We don’t want to miss the curtain.
Mrs Vaughan Williams?
No. The Birts.
Elaborate signing from MISS SHEPHERD that she is coming t halt.
No. No. No. Darling, that's us.
Stop the cab. He runs back down the street.
Sorry! You can't park here.
I've had guidance this is where it should go.
Guidance? Who from?
The Virgin Mary. I spoke to her yesterday. She was outside the post office in Parkway.
What does she know about parking?
(also having emerged from the cab) Rufus! Tell her, we're going to Glyndebourne.  22 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 12.
I need a ruler. I must measure the distance between the tyres and the kerb. One and a half inches is the ideal gap. I came across that in a Catholic motoring magazine under tips on Christian parking.
This isn't Christian parking. It's a fucking liberty. They head back up towards the cab. They get back into the cab and drive off, some of this encounter having been seen by A.B.
A.B. calls over to the van, now directly opposite his hou A.B. You didn't stay long outside 66. MISS SHEPHERD comes over the road to A.B., worried.
Not with all that din. They're not musical, are they? A.B. Who?
No. Though they go to the opera. Are you alright?
What with all this to-do, I think I’m about to be taken short. Can I use your lavatory? She is already on her way into the house. A.B. No. The flush is on the blink.
I don't mind. She is in the house. We hear her calling ‘Where is it? Wh is it?’ before the door bangs and we see A.B.’s agonised face?  23 23b 24 25
23 Later. The toilet flushes and MISS SHEPHERD comes out pas him saying nothing. Furious, A.B. calls after her. A.B. ‘Thank you?’ She ignores him.
A.B. scrubs out the lavatory.
23b 24 A.B's mother's cottage, in a village in the Yorkshire dal Lights are on downstairs. We can see A.B's MAM through th window, on the phone.
(On telephone) I’ve got a meeting at the BBC.
What about? ; A.B. (V.0.) . It’s just something I’m writing.
I thought you were coming up.
In a week or two.

head_text.subj: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT/INT. YORKSHIRE COTTAGE. DUSK

text: 25 A.B. on the phone to his mother. ALAN BENNETT at the desk
I’m on my own. A.B. I know you’re on your own.
We’re all on our own.
Can I come down there for a bit? Is it a big house?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 14. A.B. Not really. You wouldn't like it. Too many stairs.
They have these chair lift things now. (Pause) Are you still there? A.B. Yes.
The foot feller came today. A.B. Who? ALAN BENNETT begins to write this exchange down, sat at h writing desk.
The foot feller. A.B. Do you mean the chiropodist?
You've written that down.
I haven't (He has.)
I've given you some script. I’m just raw material. A.B. No, you're not. (Pause) Mam.
MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS rides her bike down the Crescent. M SHEPHERD has her door open, having just got up. She is fanning herself with a fan she has picked up somewhere.
Are you alright?
Yes. It’s the van. Gets very close.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 15.
I imagine.
You're tall.
My husband was tall. I’m Mrs. Vaughan Williams. I won’t shake hands. Gardening.
The composer? Greensleeves?
Among other things. Why? Are you musical? I don’t even know your name.
It’s Miss Shepherd, but I wouldn't want it bandied about. I’m in an incognito position, possibly.
Safe with me.
Later. MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS talking to A.B. MISS SHEPHERD the background, sorting the plastic bags under the van.
Shepherd. Drove ambulances in the war, apparently. A.B. So where did she spring from?
And a nun once. A.B. A nun?

In the convent up the street. Still, everybody's got something to hide. My brother in law's a policeman. That's Camden. People wash up here. Like me. She’d be a good subject. A.B. What for?  28 34 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 16.
You. One of your little plays. (She goes off saying -) Remember! I planted the seed!
ALAN BENNETT is at the desk, his notebook open in front o him.
No, no. I’m writing about Mam half the time as it is. One old lady’s enough. A.B. I live. You write. That's how it works.
Except you don't much. A.B. Don't what?
Live. "Put yourself into what you write." How? We're both so fucking tame.
MISS SHEPHERD is clambering into the van when LOIS approaches. In the van, a battered portable radio is tune Radio 4.
Miss Shepherd. I'm Lois, the social worker.
I don't want the social worker. I'm about to listen to the repeat of Any Answers.
I've brought you some clothes. You wrote asking for a coat.
Not during Any Answers. I'm a busy woman. I only asked for one coat.
I brought three, in case you fancied a change.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 17.
Where am I supposed to put three coats? Besides, green isn't my colour. She throws the green coat out the van on to the ground. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) Have you got a stick?
The council have that in hand. It’s been precepted for.
Will it be long enough?
Yes. It's one of our special sticks.
I don't want a special stick. I want an ordinary stick. Only longer. Shut the door.
If I should want to get in touch with you whom should I call? MISS SHEPHERD is closing the van doors.
You can try Mr Bennett at 23 only don't take any notice of what he says. He's a communist, possibly. A.B. Have you tried the people opposite, they’re nearer?
A.B. on doorstep of 23 Gloucester Crescent. A.B. Have you tried the people opposite, they’re nearer?
They said they don't relate to her. You were the one she related to.  36
Is that what they said, ‘related to'?
No. That's me. They said you were her pal. She was your girlfriend. A.B. Jesus.
Does she use your lavatory? A.B. Only in an emergency.
That might give her squatter’s rights. We'd be much happier if she moved on. A.B. We?
Camden.

36 Later. MISS SHEPHERD watches TV though Curry's window: Ed Heath arriving in Downing Street 1970. A.B. arrives with her shopping. A.B. I've got everything - sherbet lemons, Cup-a-Soup, the miniature whisky.
That's medicinal. They walk together up the High Street, MISS SHEPHERD push her child's push-chair. A.B. She seemed very understanding, the social worker.
Not understanding enough. I ask for a wheelchair and what does she get me? A walking stick. (and she looks at him meaningfully) (MORE )
And she says I don’t get an allowance unless I get an address. A.B. ‘The Van, Gloucester Crescent’ - isn’t that an address?
No it needs to be a house. A residence. Still, I may be going away soon, possibly. A.B. How long for?
Broadstairs, possibly. A.B. Why Broadstairs? Have you family there?
No. NO. A.B. Have you got any family?
I just need the air.
36a EXT. INVERNESS STREET MARKET. DAY 36a
I saw a snake this afternoon. It was coming up Parkway. It was a long grey snake. It was a boa constrictor, possibly. A.B. No...
It looked poisonous. It was keeping close to the wall. I have a feeling it may have been heading for the van. A.B. No, Miss Shepherd...

I thought I’d better warn you just to be on the safe side. I’ve had some close shaves with snakes.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 20. A.B. Listen to me Miss Shepherd. There are no boa constrictors in Camden Town.
Are you calling me a liar? I know a boa constrictor when I see one. Pitying smile from A.B. A street trader calls over.
All right, my love? You’re looking especially lovely today, sweetheart.
Don’t sweetheart me. I’m a sick woman. Dying possibly.
Well chin up love, we all got to go some time. Smells like you already have.
I do not believe in the snake, still less that it was en route for the van.
The PERRY CHILDREN playing in their garden. Piercing scre Fiona comes up.
Mummy! Mummy! There’s a snake!
Only next day I find there has been a break in at the local pet shop, so there may have been a snake on the run... A boa constrictor slithers through the flower bed.
So of course I feel guilty. The CHILDREN and FIONA run into the house shouting ‘A sna A snake!’
37b 39 40 40a 4l 43 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 21. INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY. 37b Alan Bennett sits at his desk, writing.
A real writer would have asked her about her close shaves with snakes. Only she seems to have cleared off.
A bus pulls in. MISS SHEPHERD gets out.
A POLICEMAN has stopped MISS SHEPHERD, who is in her usua long skirt etc.
A nightie? This isn’t a night dress. This style can’t have got to Broadstairs yet. And I know the law. You can’t be arrested for wearing a nightie.
What’re you doing in Broadstairs?
I am minding my own business! EXT. BROADSTAIRS RESIDENTIAL ROAD. DAY. 40a MISS SHEPHERD is on her way up the hill.

A suburban housing estate of modest bungalows, backing on fields. MISS SHEPHERD approaches the end bungalow warily. She rin the bell. A solid, respectable man (MR FAIRCHILD) opens t door. He looks anxiously over his shoulder, shuts the doo behind him, and takes MISS SHEPHERD down the side of the house towards the garden shed.
MAM is at the back-door.
Alan! Come out here.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 22. A.B. (inside) What for?
There's some massive birds on the wall. A.B. There never are. There's nothing on the wall. You're imagining things.
There are. A.B. comes to the door. There are four peacocks on the ga wall.

And there were, lined up on the garden wall, four peacocks from the Hall. So, boa constrictors in the street, peacocks on the wall, it seems that both at the northern and southern gates of my life stands a deluded woman.
A.B. is back from Yorkshire. ALAN BENNETT is at the desk. A.B. Except you just said they aren't.
Aren't what? A.B. Deluded.
Well, not in this particular instance. A.B. And they're not the same Alan, Mam and Miss Shepherd.
No, Alan, they are not. But they are both old ladies. That appears to be my niche, apparently. (MORE )

And whereas my contemporaries lovingly chronicle their first tentative investigations of the opposite sex, or their adventures in the world of journalism, I'm stuck with old ladies. He throws his notebook at A.B.

All right - I am keeping a sodding notebook, but only on the off- chance. She’s not a project. She’s not in the pipeline. I don’t want to write about her. She’s just something that's happening. A.B. So what do you want to write about?
I want to write about spies. A.B. Spies?

There you are, you see. You think that's barmy. Spies. Russia. I can't always be writing about the North. (mimicking himself) 'I was born and brought up in Leeds where my father was a butcher, and as a boy I would often go out on the bike with the orders.' It's not Proust. It's not even J.B. Priestley.
A.B. in bathroom brushing his teeth watches: PAULINE take delivery of a carpet or other upmarket item.

The houses in the crescent were built as villas for the Victorian middle class and their basements are now being enlarged by couples who are liberal in outlook but not easy with their new found prosperity. Meanwhile, RUFUS leaves home for work with his briefcase passes MISS SHEPHERD who is struggling to unscrew a bottl top.  47 46 30 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 24.

Guilt, in a word, which means that in varying degrees they tolerate Miss Shepherd, their consciences absolved by her presence. He stops and with an ill grace turns back and puts his ha out for the bottle. He unscrews it and hands it back. All done slightly furtively lest anyone observe his good turn
Snow. The two youngest PERRY CHILDREN come with FIONA and reluctant GILES and knock on the van door. They have Christmas presents for MISS SHEPHERD.
Merry Christmas! She takes the presents.
Shut the door. Shut the door! I'ma busy woman. They close the van door.
PAULINE approaches the van with a plate of leftovers, mouthing "creme briilée". MISS SHEPHERD takes it gracelessly.
A.B. and an INTERVIEWER (American) sit at the kitchen tab with a tape recorder.
What was your first play about? A.B. Public school - which, more accurately, is what you Americans call private school.
But you didn't go to public school. A.B. No, but I read about it.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 25.
And what was your next play about? A.B. Sex. I read about that too.
The PERRY CHILDREN are giving a concert on the pavement, cap for contributions. MISS SHEPHERD strides up the stree
Stop it! Stop it! Stop it this minute! Stop it! The children flee. GILES comes out of the house.
Do you have a problem?
They were making a noise.
They're children.
I am a sick woman.
You certainly are. A car beeps its horn to get MISS SHEPHERD out of the road
MISS SHEPHERD ringing the bell. A.B. opens the door.
Mr Bennett. I've worked out a way of getting on the wireless. A.B. What?

I want to do one of those phone-in programmes. It's something someone like you could get put on ina jiffy. She pushes past him and goes into the study. A.B. gets in front of her and manages to get some paper on the seat be she sits down. (There is a TV in the corner of the study.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 26. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) I could be called the Lady Behind the Curtain. Or A Woman of Britain, you see. You could take a nom de plume view of it. I see the curtain as being here, possibly. Some greeny material would do. A.B. I thought this was a phone-in.
Well? A.B. It's the radio. There's no need for a curtain at all.
Yes, well we can iron out these hiccups when the time comes. And if I come in I could catch up with some civilisation. A.B. Civilisation, what you mean the television?

Wild life. Famines. Sheep dog trials, possibly. I watch it in Curry’s window but it’s not ideal. A look between A.B. And ALAN BENNETT, who is at the desk. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT ’D) Je crois que vous passez les vacances en France. A.B. Yes. Er, oui.
J'ai 6tudié en France il y a trente- cing ans. A.B. Avant la guerre?
What guerre? A.B. La guerre mondiale numéro deux.
Oui. La deuxieme guerre mondiale.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 27. A.B. Qu'est ce que vous étudiez?
I was studying incognito 4 Paris. A.B. But what? What were you studying?

Music. The pianoforte, possibly. Have you got an old pan scrub? I'm thinking of painting the van. One of those little mop things they use to wash dishes with would do. She heads off down the corridor. A.B. How about a brush?
I've got a brush. It’s just for the first coat.
OK, she’s been a nun. Only now it turns out she’s been a musician besides, and seemingly with fluent French.
Later. MISS SHEPHERD is painting the van.

She's certainly no painter. Because today, rain notwithstanding, she moves slowly round her mobile home, thoughtfully touching up the rust patches, with crushed mimosa always a favourite shade. FIONA passes with a CHILD.
She's using the wrong paint. Cars have special paint.
(viciously) Not this one. It’s Catholic paint. The CHILD is dragged away.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 28. They pass Crescent.
And she smells.
That's because she's poor. You'd smell if we were poor. MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS on the corner of Gloucester MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS stands next to A.B.
(looking at the van) Oh...
Telling me about paint. I was in the infants' school. I won a prize for painting. A.B. But it's all lumps. You've got to mix it.
I have mixed it, only I've got some Madeira cake in it.
Cake or no cake, all Miss Shepherd's vehicles ended up looking as if they'd been given a coat of badly made custard or plastered with scrambled eggs.
Divine!
Still, there were few occasions on which one saw her genuinely happy and one of these was when she was putting paint on.

Jackson Pollock himself could not have done it better. Even with a pan scrub. An altercation across the street. An official is trying t post a removal order on the windscreen. A.B. looks up the crescent where council workers are pain yellow lines. A.B. Yellow lines.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 29.
Sorry? A.B. Parking restrictions.
Oh what a bore. A.B. She'll be illegally parked. She'll have to move on. MISS SHEPHERD is crossing the road with a removal order.
A.B. studies the form MISS SHEPHERD has brought over. A.B. It's a removal order.
I know it's a removal order. A.B. It means you'll have to drive on somewhere else.

But I'm disabled. I don't always use a walking stick and that pulls the wool over people's eyes. But I am a bona fide resident of Camden and I had rheumatic fever as a child. And mumps. A.B. I still think you'll have to move on. Go somewhere else.
Well it won’t move. There’s not enough juice. A.B. Well I’1ll get you some up the road.

I don’t like their petrol. It could go, it just needs a bit of coaxing. What I'm worried about particularly are the wheels. They're under divine protection. If I do get this other vehicle I'd like the wheels transferred.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 30. A.B. What other vehicle?
They may be miraculous, the tyres. They've only had to be pumped up once since 1964. A.B. What ‘other vehicle'?
They only cost me a fiver. A.B. Miss Shepherd, you said about another vehicle.
A van. A.B. Another van?

A newer model. A titled Catholic lady says she may get me one as an act of charity. It's Lady Wiggin only she'd prefer to remain anonymous. A.B. I bet she would. So why don’t you park it outside her house?

head_text.subj: EXT. 12 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. LADY WIGGIN'S HOUSE. DAY

text: A.B. at Lady Wiggin’s front door.
It's out of the question. A.B. There’s plenty of room.
I have neighbours. A.B. So have I.
So should I not buy her another van?  56 59 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 31. A.B. (under his breath ) Please your fucking self.
What?
A.B. returning to the house. MISS SHEPHERD calls him over
Mr Bennett...The ideal solution would be off-street parking. You know a driveway, possibly. A.B. So what are you going to do?
Play it by ear.
A man in his mid sixties (UNDERWOOD), tall and sinister, approaches the van.

Lady. (tapping lightly on the side of the van.) Are you there. Her side window is open a little and he slips his fingers inside. UNDERWOOD (CONT’D) Is this a bad moment? Have you got something for me? MISS SHEPHERD (unseen) bangs his fingers with a hammer or brick. UNDERWOOD (CONT’D) You bad bitch! You dirty lying bitch! He gives the van a great bang. A.B. opens the bathroom wi and calls across the road. A.B. Can I help you?  61 62 60 63 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 32.
Good evening to you, sir. Finding myself in the vicinity, I am taking this opportunity to pay my compliments to Margaret. A.B. Margaret?
An old friend from way back. I've been out of the game for a while...you know how it is. A.B. You mean Miss Shepherd.
Shepherd, is it? Very good. A.B. She'll be asleep

Of course. I will bid you good night, sir. I will call again when my schedule permits. A.B. goes inside. UNDERWOOD lingers, and taps lightly on van. Two £20 notes are slid through the window. He taps again. Then another £20 note. UNDERWOOD (CONT’D) Thank you..
MISS SHEPHERD being shaken around - a fairly frightening scene.
A.B. looks out of the window and sees a commotion outside
A workman's van, with two young men in their twenties, wh get either side of the van and start shaking it and shout at MISS SHEPHERD.
A.B., comes out as - jeering - the two guys drive off.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 33. A.B. Approaches the back of the van. A.B. Miss Shepherd. No answer.
Miss Shepherd. Are you alright?
(from within the van) I think so. What was it about? It wasn't the police, was it? A.B. No. They were louts. But if you choose to live like this it’s what you must expect.
I didn't choose. I was chosen.
A.B. is still in his dressing gown. A.B. Well that settles it.
You think? A.B. I can't always be looking out for her. I'm not her keeper. I mean, what happens to work? I think she should either go...or...
Or what? A.B. Or bring the van into the drive where we can forget about her. Actually, that's why some men marry...so they don't have to think any more about their wives.

That's not bad. (He is writing it down)  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 34. A.B. Yes. Except it's Proust. And it'll only be for a few months until she decides where she's going. It'll be easier. But it's not kindness.

No. (He reads from one of his notebooks ) ‘Good nature, or what is often considered as such, is the most selfish of all virtues: it is nine times out of ten mere indolence of disposition.' A.B. That's not you?
Hazlitt. And it's will. Pure will. She's known what she's wanted all along.

location: OUR LADY OF HAL R.C. CHURCH, CAMDEN. DAY 74

text: MISS SHEPHERD is in the confessional with someone on the outside waiting his turn.
The soul in question did confess, though in guarded terms, in Rome, in Holy Year, though I'm not sure the priest understood English. Do I look like a joy rider?

(patiently) My child. You have already been given absolution for this particular sin. I have given you it myself on several occasions. Have faith. Absolution is not like a bus pass. It does not run out. We see MISS SHEPHERD come out of the box as the next pers take her place and recoils.
Christ.
(from behind the grille) There is air freshener behind the virgin.  65
The man picks up a can of air freshener.
A dinner party in progress: the neighbours and Donald, a young actor, discuss A.B. who is currently not in the roo A silence.
He's a saint. Ralph was the same. Some people are just kind.
Kind? This is London, Ursula. Nobody is kind.
And now the old cow's got a foot in the door. He’s a fool.
Who else would do it?
Well, we might... it’s just the girls...
I'm just an unemployed actor and I don't know the lady but can I ask something? What makes her Alan's problem?
Darling. She is a human being.
Only just.
(to Donald) Changing the subject. When are we going to find Alan a girl? Silence. GILES rolls his eyes. FIONA tries again.
Josephine's pregnant again.
Oh no! Actually, I'm just trying to think who Josephine is.
The hamster.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 36. A.B. returns carrying a fresh bottle of wine. A.B. Here we are.
We were just saying how grateful she'll be.
At the van.

Put the van in your drive? That hadn’t occurred to me. I don't know. It might not be convenient. A.B. No. I've thought it over. Believe me, Miss Shepherd. It's all right. Just till you sort yourself out.

Not convenient for you. Convenient for me. You're not doing me a favour, you know. I have got other fish to fry. A man on the pavement told me if I went south of the river I'd be welcomed with open arms. A.B. watches her as she goes back to the van and starts t sort through her clothes.
I was about to do her a good turn but, as ever, it was not without thoughts of strangulation. She would come into the garden, yes...but only as favour to me.

MISS SHEPHERD walks round the old van for the last time. the broken windscreen she paints a cross. Her belongings been piled on the pavement outside No. 23. We see the council truck towing away the now empty van as new (though second-hand) van driven by MISS SHEPHERD with usual battery of hand signals comes down the Crescent. ALAN BENNETT watches from the study window. The neighbour watch from the street. Van being slowly driven into drive, comes to a stop (almo  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 37. A.B. Have you put on the handbrake?
I am about to do so.
Whereupon she applies the handbrake with such determination that, like Excalibur, it can never afterwards be released.

A.B. coming into the study, and going to the living room window. Behind him, a young man comes in, pulling on a sh or T-shirt. He has a small overnight bag. A.B.'s POV of t van, MISS SHEPHERD inside praying, her paraffin light on.

Now she is on the premises, I sometimes get a glimpse of Miss Shepherd praying and it is seldom a tranquil or a meditative process, the fervour of her intercessions rocking her to and fro. What is it she’s wanting forgiveness for? I used to pray myself when I was young. But never like this. I'd never done anything. But what has she done?
Inside the van, MISS SHEPHERD prays, a reproduction Assumption of the Virgin among her possessions.
O Virgo Fidelis, first leader of all creatures, intercede on my behalf. I hunger and thirst for the fulfilment of a just era and utterly trust in possible light received.
A.B. turns back to the young man on the sofa.
Who’s the old bat? A.B. Oh, she’s...a friend.
A friend? A.B. Someone I know.
Weird. A.B. Maybe.
Actually I think I better be off. A.B. Yeah? You don't want to stay for coffee or anything?
Nah.

72 From Miss Shepherd's POV we see A.B. saying goodbye to th YOUNG MAN leaving. The YOUNG MAN waves at the gate. A.B. Is about to go back inside when MISS SHEPHERD’S hand comes through the window of the van.
Mr Bennett. That young man. Did he have an earring? A.B. He did.
You want to be careful.
MAM and A.B. having tea, preparing to leave.
She'll be wanting to move in next.
Said my mother, who has been in London on a state visit.
Why didn't you tell me she was in the drive?
75  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 39. A.B. I forgot.
I got a whiff of her when I first came. A right nasty bad dishcloth smell. Well, she's in the garden. Next it'll be the house. What will folks think? A.B. This is London. Nobody thinks anything.
It's with her being a nun, not having got off. They get thwarted. An educated woman and living like that. Mind you, you're going down the same road. A.B. Me?

No cloth on the table. No holder for the toilet roll. Given time I could have this place spotless. A.B. You've got a home. You wouldn't want to live here. MAM looks at A.B. It is plain she would like to do just t
They are climbing the stairs to the hall.
Where does she go to the lav? A.B. It's something to do with plastic bags.
What sort of plastic bags? A.B. Stout ones, I hope. You’ve not met her, do you want to?
No. With her being educated I wouldn't know what to say.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 40. A.B. opening the door, the van visible in the doorway. A waiting.
Give us a kiss. When will you be coming up next? A.B. Soon.
The thing is, I keep seeing a car in the car park. A.B. That's slightly to be expected, isn't it?
At night. Watching. A.B. Are you taking your tablets?
When I remember. She looks out at the van, and MISS SHEPHERD going about h business.
She should be in a home. Where does she go to the lav? A.B. I told you.
Looked after. A place where they'll wash her and make her presentable. I'm surprised they let her roam the streets. Mam walks to the back of the van where MISS SHEPHERD is sitting.
Good morning. No response from Miss Shepard.
It’s like a fairy story. A Parable, in which the guilty is gulled in to devising a sentence for someone innocent only to find it is their own doom they have pronounced. (MORE)
78a 78b 81 82 98 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 4l.
Because my mother is much closer to being put in a home than Miss Shepherd Mam gets into the taxi. A.B. (to Mam) You got your purse?
Yes...I do miss your Dad. Give us a kiss. I asked our Gordon when he was a pilot did he go behind the clouds? A.B. And did he?
I can’t remember. He's a love, though. I know that.
EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 78a MISS SHEPHERD paints the new van yellow. EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 78b Later, she festoons the van with Union Jacks and other si jubilee paraphernalia.
MAM arrives at the front door with her shopping, alone.
Two Jehovah's Witnesses come up the drive and ring the fr door bell. A.B. comes to the door.
Good afternoon. Does Jesus Christ dwell in this house? A.B. No. Try the van.
MISS SHEPHERD at Curry's window watching Mrs Thatcher on  80 86 90 104 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 42.
Miss Shepherd arrives home with an old TV in her push cha Later: A.B. running an electric cable from the house to t van.
A.B. watches as another young man leaves the house. The y man looks into the van where MISS SHEPHERD is watching ne coverage of the Falklands War. She sees him peering in.
(in the van) Clear off, you nosey blighter!
They come round the corner of Inverness Street and reach 23. MISS SHEPHERD goes towards the van.
Mr Bennett. A.B. Yes?
These men. Who come late at night. I know what they are. A.B. (under his breath) Jesus.
They're communists. Else why would they come at night?
MISS SHEPHERD in the van watching television. UNDERWOOD comes into the drive and taps on the van.
(calling, menacingly) I like the new vehicle. Not a mark on it. (giving the van a great bang) Not a bloody scratch. What's your name now, Margaret?  Pause. THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 43.
(from van) My name's Mary. Go away.
Mary is it now? Mary what?
Mary what? He gives a great bang on the side of the van.
I'll call the police. UNDERWOOD pulls the van door open. She is cowering inside

Call the police? I don't think you will, you two-faced pisshole. Because calling the police is just what you didn't do. Apropos of which I think another contribution is due. Front door opens and A.B. comes out Beat. A.B. Can I help you? What's all this din?
No din, sir. Margaret and I were just taking a stroll down memory lane.
Don't Margaret me. That name is buried to sin. A.B. You came before.
Of course, this isn't the van, is it? A.B. She had another one.
That is kind of you. A homeless woman. A thankless soul and not over-salubrious. Goodbye Margaret.  105
I thought you said your name was Mary.
It is. A.B. Why does he call you Margaret?
He's taken too much to drink, on an empty stomach, possibly. A.B. It is your name: Mary Shepherd?
Subject to the Roman Catholic Church in her rights and to amendment, yes.

It’s obviously not her name, and though it's long enough since she drove the van into the garden, I’m still too polite to ask who she is; let alone what this fellow wants who materialises at regular intervals and comes braying on the side of the van. Music has something to do with it..
ALAN BENNETT at the desk. Both looking out towards the va The doors at the back are still open.
But is it just the noise, or music itself? A.B. puts some music on. Through the window they watch MISS SHEPHERD come out of t van and hurry to the front door.
(shouting) I can hear the music. I can hear it. Why must you play that? I can hear it! A.B. goes to the door.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 45.
MISS SHEPHERD at the door. The music still playing. A.B. How can you dislike music? You used to play the piano.
How do you know that? A.B. You told me.
I didn't say I didn't like it. I don't want to hear it, that's all. A.B. returns to the study.
Should she speak now? Should she explain? A.B. She never lets on. Never explains.
Well maybe she should.
I was once left alone in a room in the convent.
We see YOUNG MISS SHEPHERD, a novice.
They didn’t leave novices alone normally. And there was a piano there. I tried it and it was open. YOUNG MISS SHEPHERD starts to play. An OLD NUN comes in quietly.

It needed tuning and some of the notes were dead but it sounded more beautiful to me than any of the pianos I'd ever played. Then suddenly the mistress of the novices came in .. crept in possibly, because I didn’t hear her. She said: MISTRESS slams the piano cover.  108 109 114 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 46.
That was what God wanted. And that I'd been told before. I said - Couldn't I just play some hymns for us to sing to? She said that was arguing, and I’d never make a nun if I argued.
An Old Peoples Home overlooking the sea at Weston Super M A.B. arrives in a taxi.
A.B. sitting beside his MOTHER, on a bench in the garden.

So with painful symmetry my mother ends up in a home in Western Super Mare, while her derelict counterpart now resides in my garden. Putting my mother in a home I see as some sort of failure. And giving the other a home, that's a failure too.

A.B. is upstairs. There is a distant sound getting nearer the time. Suddenly (and possibly with a bang) we see thro the window a three-wheeler Robin Reliant draw up. A.B. Oh Jesus. She's got herself a three wheeler.
A.B. walking round the Reliant now parked outside the hou ALAN BENNETT watching from the window. A.B. Where will you park it?
In the residents' parking. A.B. You haven't got a permit.  Pause. Pause. Pause. THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 47.
I have. I got one yesterday. A.B. You never told me.
You'd only have raised objections if I had. A.B. Have you insured it?
I don't need insuring. It's like the van. I'm insured in heaven. A.B. So who pays if you have an accident? The Pope?
I shan't have an accident. A.B. What if you run into something?
I shan't run into anything. I'm an experienced driver. I drove ambulances in the blackout. A.B. What if someone runs into you?
Miss Shepherd. What if someone runs into you?
(fiercely ) You have no business saying that.
Why do you say that? No one is going to run into me.
Where's the key? A.B. What key?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 48.
The car key. I put it down. A.B. I haven't got it.
You have. You've taken it. A.B. I have not.
You're lying. You don't want me to have the car so you've taken the key. A.B. Don't shout.

I have to shout because of your ignorance. People coming and going all hours of the day and night, I'd be better off in a ditch. Give me the key. A.B. I haven't got your sodding key. What's that round your neck? This. This. (He pushes her and she falls against the car.) The key. The sodding key. MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS comes past.
Having fun? A.B. (Beat) Shouldn’t you say sorry?
I’ve no time for sorry. Sorry is for God. A.B. and MISS SHEPHERD slowly recover, he watching her retreat into the van. ALAN BENNETT is at the desk.
This was the only time I ever touched her. It was not because she was calling me a liar, but because she seemed mad. It was my mother.
(calling through the study window to ALAN BENNETT) It's always Mam you compare her with. They are not the same. I don't like them even sharing the same sentence.
A.B. watching at the window.
These days it’s almost as if we’re married. MISS SHEPHERD is painting the Reliant.
‘How’s your old lady?’, they say. Which is what people call a wife: your Old Lady.
A.B. sitting in the stalls during a technical rehearsal w the director of his new play.
How’s your old lady? A.B. She's still there. I'm still here.
Your mother died, didn't she? A.B. No. She's still here too. She was in hospital, but now she's ina home. Except she's not all there, you know. She's not anywhere.
Should we make that plain in the play? A.B. No. That's classified information.
A.B. watching at the window. MISS SHEPHERD is painting th Reliant.

Years ago Mam wanted Miss Shepherd put in a home, but she's still on the loose. Of course, whether she's all there or not is anyone's guess. She turns towards him and calls through the window. She i splattered with yellow paint.

Mr Bennett. I don't like the three- wheeler standing in the street. If you pushed the van in front of your window I could get the Reliant in there on the drive. There's tons of room. A.B. So I have the van and the Reliant?
I've had guidance that's where it should be. In terms of vandals. A.B. Guidance from whom?
I'm not at liberty to speak. I think I may contact my new social worker. A.B. What for? You always say you don't want the social worker.
(Returns to painting the Reliant) I've had guidance she might help.
A.B. now with the new social worker, MISS BRISCOE. A.B. I don’t want a used car lot.
Mary says...  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 51. A.B. Mary who?
Mary, your Lady in the Van. Didn't you know her name was Mary? A.B. I suppose I did. I always call her Miss Shepherd.

We all have names. Perhaps if you called her by her name and she called you by yours? Alan, Mary...You never know, it might be easier to talk things through. A.B. Through? There is no through. How do you talk things through with someone who has conversations with the Virgin Mary? You talk things through with Isaiah Berlin, maybe, who in comparison with Miss Shepherd is a man of few words, but you do not talk things through with her because you don't get through.

Alan. I'm getting a bit of hostility here. I realise for you this may be a steep learning curve... A.B. No. It is not a steep learning curve. I have never been on a so called learning curve. I’m about as likely to be found on a learning curve as I am on the ski slopes at Zermatt. And besides, her name isn't Mary.
Oh? A.B. Some people seem to think it's Margaret. And it isn't even Shepherd.
I have her down as Mary. A.B. Yes, and you presumably have her down as a rational human being.  125 125a 119a 125b 126 127 128 130 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 52.
The Reliant pulls up and parks on the front. MISS SHEPHER gets out.

A.B. comes out with some rubbish. He sees a small brown t on the side of the bin. EXT. BROADSTAIRS. DAY 125a Later: MISS SHEPHERD on the beach eating chips from newspaper. EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 119a A.B. has plastic bags over his hands as he begins to remo the turd from the bin. EXT. BROADSTAIRS. DAY 125b Then: she sits on a children's carousel, as it revolves carrying her and two or three small children.

MISS SHEPHERD is served with a large ice cream sundae. EXT. CHURCH HALL, ON A ROAD NEAR THE SEAFRONT. DAY -— 127 A sign saying 'SENIOR CITIZENS CLUB. TEA, COFFEE AND CAKE ALL WELCOME’ MISS SHEPHERD goes in.

A gathering of pensioners. A young woman is about to play piano. MISS SHEPHERD is at the back helping herself to tea and biscuits. She hasn't noticed the pianist. Then the woman plays - Chopin, say. MISS SHEPHERD is about to flee, hesitates, then stays and listens, transported.

We see the Reliant Robin slide into view and park not far from the end bungalow, and wait.  131 124 129 132 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 53. A woman (EDITH) comes out with a shopping bag. MISS SHEPH crouches down.
We see MISS SHEPHERD'S slippered feet as she is crammed i a corner. The door opens. The solid, respectable man comes in, not looking at MISS SHEPHERD at first.
Hello, Margaret. He looks at her warily.
The Reliant on the road.
MISS SHEPHERD at the scene of the crash. She kneels, praying for forgiveness, as a car beeps its h behind her.
The Reliant is back, now parked a little way up the Cresc A.B. with his bike trying to look into the van when RUFUS PAULINE appear.
What’s happened to Stirling Moss?.. I haven’t seen her at the wheel recently. A.B. Taking a well-earned break, I imagine. The Dordogne possibly.
Really?
Pauline. A.B. Her car's back. But I haven't seen her around for a bit. I wonder if she's alright.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 54.
Am I right in thinking that large many-contoured stain at the back of her frock denotes incontinence? A.B. Well, I don't think it's a fashion statement.
Oh, darling. What you must be hoping is that one of these days she'll just slip away.
Don't you believe it. That's what happens in plays. In life going downhill is an uphill job.
How's your mother? A.B. Same. Sits. Smiles. Sleeps.
Are you all right? A.B. Me? Yes, why? Just going to the theatre.
Not upset about your play? A.B. No.
I read a good review the other day. A.B. I was told they were all good.
Oh, they are, I'm sure.
We enjoyed it - though I hadn't realised it was just going to be you and nobody else. A.B. Well, yes. It's a monologue.
Yes I suppose. I'm just amazed how you remember it all.  133 134 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 55.
The review I saw was particularly perceptive about you. A.B. Really? Saying what?
That you couldn't make your mind up. A.B. About what?
Anything really. It meant in a good way. A.B. Thanks. A.B. cycles off.
Actually I couldn't make it out at all. What was it about?
Him as usual. Not coming clean.
What about?
What do you think?
The National Theatre seen from Waterloo Bridge. On the electronic billboard: TALKING HEADS BY ALAN BENNETT
A scene from 'A Chip in the Sugar'.

«+. When I came down again she's still sat there with her hat and coat on. She said “Graham. My one aim in life is for you to be happy. If I thought that by dying it would make you happy, I would.” I said, “Mam, your dying wouldn't make me happy. In fact the reverse. It would make me unhappy. (MORE )
135 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 56.
Anyway, Mam, you're not going to die.” She said, “No. I'm not going to die. I'm going to get married. And the honeymoon is in Tenerife. Have one of your tablets.”
A.B. cycles down Gloucester Crescent

So for the umpteenth time I bike back from the theatre where I've been talking about my mother. Though at least I know where my mother is. A.B. taps on the van window. A.B. Miss Shepherd. Miss Shepherd. (no answer) I don't like it. ALAN BENNETT has come to the window.
So look in. A.B. No.
Are you scared? A.B. No.

Not of the body. You're scared this may be the end of the story and now I'm going to have to write it. Still, now she's gone I can make it up. Narrative freedom. Whoopee! A.B. (tapping on van.) Miss Shepherd. Pause.
Miss Shepherd.
Go on...  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 57. A.B. very nervously opens the back door of the van. MISS SHEPHERD appears from further up the Crescent.
What are you doing? Both ALAN BENNETTS react, startled.
Looking at my things? A.B. I thought you might be ill. Dead.
Dead? Me? A.B. I was concerned.
You were nosy. A.B. I hadn't seen you. I’m sorry. A.B. beats a retreat to the house, pursued by MISS SHEPHE
I'm not dead. You'll know when I'm dead. A.B. I'm sorry. He goes into the house and shuts the front door.
Dead! Me! I shan't die in a hurry, I can tell you. Dead! Don't make me laugh.
She didn't die then, and nor did my mother.
Through the window, the tide is out. A.B. by MAM'S bed, talking to a DOCTOR.
But as the years passed both of them were beginning to fade.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 58.
As you can appreciate it's difficult to take a history but I'm right in thinking she hasn't been a smoker? A.B. No.
Not been a smoker, doesn't drink, all things considered a very healthy woman. A.B. You think? There is an awkward silence.

This is a woman who has broken her hip. And of course in someone younger and in better circumstances we would give them antibiotics. At your mother's age and in her state of mind, one wonders if this is altogether kind. A.B. If you don't give her antibiotics what will happen?
She may recover or not. She could just sleep away. You mustn't reproach yourself. You've done all...more than can be expected.
A.B. arrives home by cab. MISS SHEPHERD is now wheelchair bound. Her wheelchair has an aerial with a Union Jack pennant. A.B. (to cab driver) Thank you.
Mr Bennett. Where've you been? A.B. Seeing my mother.
How is she?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 59. A.B. The same. She doesn't remember me now.
I'm not surprised. She doesn't see you very often. Will you write about me? ALAN BENNETT is in the window, writing. A.B. I don't know (sotto to ALAN BENNETT) She never said this.
So?
I've heard you on the wireless. Does she know that? A.B. How can she? She doesn't know who she is.
That's what you think. Using your mother. You should be ashamed of yourself. A.B. She didn't say this.
